Title: Connections between the medial temporal cortex and the CA1 subfield of the hippocampal formation in the Japanese monkey (Macaca fuscata)
Abstract: The connections between the medial temporal cortical areas and CA1 of the hippocampus were examined in the Japanese monkey (Macaca fuscata) by means of retrograde and anterograde tract-tracing methods with wheat germ agglutinin-conjugated horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP) and fluorescent dyes (Fast Blue and Diamidino Yellow). The posterior parahippocampal (areas TF1, TF2, and TH), perirhinal (areas 35 and 36), and ventral inferotemporal areas (areas TEav and TEpv) were reciprocally connected with CA1. Projection fibers from CA1 to the medial temporal cortical areas originated in the pyramidal cell layer, whereas those from the medial temporal cortical areas to CA1 terminated in the molecular layer. Each of these cortical areas was reciprocally connected with the entire rostrocaudal extent of CA1. However, the intensity of the connections varied along the rostrocaudal axis of CA1: areas TH and TF2 were connected most markedly with the anterior and middle parts of CA1, respectively. Areas TF, 35, 36, TEav, and TEpv were connected predominantly with the posterior part of CA1. In the coronal plane of CA1, labeled cells were located in proximal CA1 (i. e., near the prosubiculum), but not in distal CA1 (i.e., near CA2). The medial temporal cortical areas in direct reciprocal connection with CA1 were presumed to be involved in the memory system, especially in the system for declarative memory. @BrainMaps_Delineation.Region_Parcellation: Hippocampal formation, ento- and perirhinal cortex, parahippocampal areas TF and TH, and inferotemporal area TE
@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: "The loci extent of the medial temporal cortical areas that were examined in the present study are shown diagrammatically in figures 1A and 10. The nomenclature of the cortical areas was taken basically from that of Brodmann (1909), Amaral et al. (1987), Bonin and Bailey 81947), and Tranel et al. (1988). The hippocampal formation was subdivided according to Lorente de Nò (1934) and Rosene and Van Hoesen (1987) (see Figs. 3, 7, 9)." (p. 284)

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Amaral et al. (1987) proposed that both areas of the monkey should be included in the perirhinal cortex of the monkey, because both areas projected in a similar way to the entorhinal cortex. In the present study, we basically adopted their terminology for areas 35 and 36." (p. 285)

"The border between CA1 and the prosubiculum was determined according to the criteria of Rosene and Van Hoesen (1987): ... The hippocamüal-amygdaloid transition area (HATA) and CA1´ of Rosene and Van Hoesen (1987) were identified at the rostral levels of the hippocampal formation (Fig. 3A). The prosubiculum and subiculum were demarcated medial to CA1 (Fig. 3). The hippocampal formation was also divided rostrocaudally into the genu, the anterior part, the middle part, and the posterior part according to Rosene and Van Hoesen (1987) (Figs. 3, 10)." "Area TE had a prominent layer IV and well-differentiated layers V and VI, as described by Bonin and Bailey (1947). ...Area TE was subdivided into the posterodorsal, anterodorsal, posteroventral, and anteroventral parts (areas TEpd, TEad, TEpv, and TEav, respectively), as described in our previous studies (Iwai and Yukie, 1988; Yukie and Iwai, 1988). More recently, Saleem and Tanaka (1996) subdivided the anterior part of area TE into areas TEav and TEad on the basis of the staining pattern in parvalbumin immunohistochemistry. The border between areas TEad and TEav in the present study was determined on the basis of Saleem and Tanaka (1996). Because the dorsal parts of area TE (areas TEad and TEpd) were not connected directly with the hippocampal formation (Iwai and Yukie, 1988; Yuke and Iwai, 1988), these parts of area TE were excluded from the present study." (p. 285)

"The border between CA1 and the prosubiculum was determined according to the criteria of Rosene and Van Hoesen (1987): ... The hippocamüal-amygdaloid transition area (HATA) and CA1´ of Rosene and Van Hoesen (1987) were identified at the rostral levels of the hippocampal formation (Fig. 3A). The prosubiculum and subiculum were demarcated medial to CA1 (Fig. 3). The hippocampal formation was also divided rostrocaudally into the genu, the anterior part, the middle part, and the posterior part according to Rosene and Van Hoesen (1987) (Figs. 3, 10)." (p. 287) "The loci extent of the medial temporal cortical areas that were examined in the present study are shown diagrammatically in figures 1A and 10. The nomenclature of the cortical areas was taken basically from that of Brodmann (1909), Amaral et al. (1987), Bonin and Bailey 81947), and Tranel et al. (1988). "Area TE had a prominent layer IV and well-differentiated layers V and VI, as described by Bonin and Bailey (1947). ...Area TE was subdivided into the posterodorsal, anterodorsal, posteroventral, and anteroventral parts (areas TEpd, TEad, TEpv, and TEav, respectively), as described in our previous studies (Iwai and Yukie, 1988; Yukie and Iwai, 1988). More recently, Saleem and Tanaka (1996) subdivided the anterior part of area TE into areas TEav and TEad on the basis of the staining pattern in parvalbumin immunohistochemistry. The border between areas TEad and TEav in the present study was determined on the basis of Saleem and Tanaka (1996). Because the dorsal parts of area TE (areas TEad and TEpd) were not connected directly with the hippocampal formation (Iwai and Yukie, 1988; Yuke and Iwai, 1988), these parts of area TE were excluded from the present study." (p. 285)

The border between areas TEad and TEav in the present study was determined on the basis of Saleem and Tanaka (1996). Because the dorsal parts of area TE (areas TEad and TEpd) were not connected directly with the hippocampal formation (Iwai and Yukie, 1988; Yuke and Iwai, 1988), these parts of area TE were excluded from the present study." publication.title: Connections between the medial temporal cortex and the CA1 subfield of the hippocampal formation in the Japanese monkey (Macaca fuscata)
publication.abstract: The connections between the medial temporal cortical areas and CA1 of the hippocampus were examined in the Japanese monkey (Macaca fuscata) by means of retrograde and anterograde tract-tracing methods with wheat germ agglutinin-conjugated horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP) and fluorescent dyes (Fast Blue and Diamidino Yellow). The posterior parahippocampal (areas TF1, TF2, and TH), perirhinal (areas 35 and 36), and ventral inferotemporal areas (areas TEav and TEpv) were reciprocally connected with CA1. Projection fibers from CA1 to the medial temporal cortical areas originated in the pyramidal cell layer, whereas those from the medial temporal cortical areas to CA1 terminated in the molecular layer. Each of these cortical areas was reciprocally connected with the entire rostrocaudal extent of CA1. However, the intensity of the connections varied along the rostrocaudal axis of CA1: areas TH and TF2 were connected most markedly with the anterior and middle parts of CA1, respectively. Areas TF, 35, 36, TEav, and TEpv were connected predominantly with the posterior part of CA1. In the coronal plane of CA1, labeled cells were located in proximal CA1 (i. e., near the prosubiculum), but not in distal CA1 (i.e., near CA2). The medial temporal cortical areas in direct reciprocal connection with CA1 were presumed to be involved in the memory system, especially in the system for declarative memory.
